title: Emotional Processing
description: Understand how you handle and share your feelings.

questions.text: What emotional need is most important to me in our relationship?

therapeutic.rationale: Core emotional needs drive relationship satisfaction. Consistent love needs daily reassurance; being heard needs active listening; goal support needs championing; being desired needs attraction shown. When our primary need goes unmet, we feel the relationship is failing even if other areas are strong.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different core needs require different relationship investments. The consistency-seeker needs daily evidence; the heard-seeker needs deep listening; the desired-seeker needs attraction expressed. Know and prioritize your partner's primary need.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared core needs mean you're both seeking the same emotional nourishment. You understand the hunger because it's the same. Make sure you're both fed.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What emotional need, when met, makes the relationship feel right? What happens when it goes unmet for too long? Does your partner know this is your deepest need?

questions.text: When I'm upset, what helps me calm down?

therapeutic.rationale: Emotional regulation strategies differ significantly between people. Some co-regulate through words; others through physical contact; others need solitude to self-regulate; others process by talking. Understanding how your partner calms down helps you support their regulation rather than interfere with it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different calming needs often clash. The touch-calmer may feel rejected by the space-needer; the talker may feel abandoned by the silence-needer. State what you need: 'I need 10 minutes alone, then let's talk.'
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched calming strategies mean you can help each other regulate in the same way. You instinctively provide what soothes.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you're upset, what actually helps you calm down? What makes it worse? Does your partner know what helps versus what escalates?

questions.text: What makes me feel most prioritized in your life?
choices: When you make time for me despite being busy
When you choose me over other options
When you ask about my inner world
When you include me in your decisions

therapeutic.rationale: Feeling prioritized is essential—we need to know we matter to our partner. Time-making shows we're worth schedule adjustments; choosing shows preference; asking shows interest in our depth; inclusion shows partnership. How prioritization lands varies by person.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different prioritization needs mean different things make you feel chosen. The choice-seeker needs visible selection; the inclusion-seeker needs collaborative decisions. Show priority in your partner's language.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared prioritization cues mean the same actions make you both feel chosen. You'll naturally prioritize each other in ways that register.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When do you feel most prioritized by your partner? When do you feel like an afterthought? What would help you feel consistently chosen?

questions.text: How do I prefer to share my feelings with you?

therapeutic.rationale: How we share feelings reflects our processing style. Some need dedicated conversation space; others integrate emotionally as they go; others communicate through behavior; others need solitary processing first. Partners with different sharing styles may misinterpret each other—the gradual sharer may seem distant to the deep-conversation seeker.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different sharing styles create miscommunication. The planned-conversation person may feel their action-sharing partner never opens up; the process-first partner may feel pressured by immediate demands. Adapt to each other's pace and style.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched sharing styles mean emotional conversations flow naturally. You're on the same wavelength about when and how to process together.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you prefer to share difficult feelings? Does your partner know your style? What happens when they push for a style that doesn't fit you?

questions.text: What helps me feel emotionally recharged after a hard day?

therapeutic.rationale: Recharging needs vary based on introversion/extroversion and love languages. Some recharge through togetherness; others through physical contact; others through verbal support; others need solitude before connection. Knowing how your partner recharges helps you give them what they need after depleting days.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different recharging needs may conflict at day's end. The together-recharger may feel rejected by the alone-time-first partner; the verbal-support person may need to process before other activities. Communicate what you need after hard days.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched recharging styles mean evenings flow naturally. You'll both want to recharge the same way, making end-of-day transitions smooth.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: After a really hard day, what do you need to feel recharged? Does your partner provide this? What happens when you can't recharge in your preferred way?
